Period ended July 27, 1923. The number of persons registered at the Employment Exchanges as whollyunemployed at the 23rd July was 1,184,900, an increase of 4,239 over the previousweek. POSITION IN CHIEF INDUSTRIES.COAL-MINING. Generally, there has been some slackening of activity due to various causes.In the Bristol and Forest of Dean coal-fields the reduced demand for house coalhas checked the steadiness of employment at some pits, but others remain busy.The same cause accounts for diminished activity in the Midlands, where the positionis also affected by lack of demand on account of the prolonged depression in thepottery industry and by delays in shipment caused by the dockers' dispute. Inthe Yorkshire and Durham fields work is steady, apart from a local set-back dueto an explosion at the Maltby Main Colliery. The Lancashire coal-field shows afalling-off in activity. Employment in Scotland has remained good. Trade isquiet in Wales, the output having been diminished owing to the incidence of theannual holidays.IRON AND STEEL. There have been fluctuations in employment in the Midlands, but no material improvement can be recorded. Unemployment on the North-East Coast hascontinued acute, and prospects of future activity are still very poor. Trade inScotland is depressed, most firms having closed down for an extended period overthe annual holidays. Employment has been good in North Wales, and, on thewhole, satisfactory in South Wales.SHIPBUILDING AND SHIP-REPAIRING. Apart from a certain amount of repairing work, there is little activity at the yards on the South-West Coast. On the North-East Coast the continuance of theindustrial dispute among the boilermakers has resulted in acute depression in theindustry, and allied industries are also adversely affected. There is a fair amountof repair work being done on the Merseyside, but little constructional work. no improvement is expected in Scotland until the dispute is settled. Although thesituation in Wales is unsatisfactory, a slight improvement has been noticed at theChannel ports.ENGINEERING. The situation in London and the Home Counties is uncertain. The improve-ment in the South-West Counties has continued. In the Midlands seasonalSUMMARY OF UNEMPLOYMENT SITUATION. depression is adversely affecting employment in the motor and cycle section; but ingeneral engineering the gradual improvement continues. A further slightimprovement has occurred in Yorkshire and the North of England, and the outlookat some centres is hopeful. Ma,rine engineering, however, is depressed as the resultof the boilermakers' dispute. In Lancashire unemployment and short-time workingcontinue. The annual holidays in Scotland have been extended in many casesowing chiefly to lack of orders, but some signs of improvement are evident. in wales, the slow and steady improvement has been maintained.TEXTILES. " Cotton. Employment in the fine spinning section in Lancashire has continuedsatisfactory, and mills spinning Egyptian cotton are generally working full time.In the weaving section no improvement can be reported and production is stillconsiderably curtailed. The depression in Yorkshire continues. Hosiery, Woollen and Worsted. The hosiery trade in the Midlands has shown a slight improvement. In the woollen and worsted industry the position is unsatisfactory in Yorkshire with much short-time working, while a decline isnoticeable in Scotland. Lace. In the Midlands some improvement is perceptible in the lace curtainand plain net sections, but there has been a further decline in the Lever's section. Silk. Unemployment remains considerable, and the immediate outlook in theMidlands is not promising, as trade usually becomes quieter at this period of theyear. Jute. Trade has been quiet owing to the holiday season. The outlookappears good.BUILDING. There has been very little change in the position. Employment generallycontinues good, and the demand for skilled operatives has not diminished.BOOT AND SHOE. There has been little improvement in the South-Western Counties. The recentimprovement in the Midlands has not been maintained.CLOTHING. The dressmaking and millinery trades have improved in the London area, butthe wholesale clothing - section has been slack. In the South-Western Counties,employment at some centres is good. The position in the Midlands is unchanged.POTTERY AND GLASS. , Unemployment and short-time working in the pottery trade have increased inthe Midlands.TRANSPORT. The dispute at the London Docks continued and has affected other industries.Workers in the Bristol area have returned to work and are very busy. The disputehas resulted in decreased activity on the North-East Coast, especially at Hull.Increased activity at other centres occurred owing to the diversion of vessels fromports affected by the dispute. On the North-West Coast employment has generallybeen resumed, and additional men are being engaged to cope with the arrears ofwork. A slight improvement has been recorded in South Wales, but the generalsituation is still unsatisfactory. C. A. MONTAGUE iSARLOW, Ministry of Labour. I. DETAILED UNEMPLOYMENT FIGURES. 1. (B.) Emergency Works and other Measures. A full statement of the measures taken in the autumn of 1920 and of the latermeasures from autumn 1921 onwards has been set out in previous issues of thisReport. At least 300,000 men have had employment on these schemes at various times, and at the present time over 129,000 men are employed, exclusive of the workprovided for men in ancillary occupations and the effect of the Export credits scheme. (C.) Extensions of Remedial Measures during the Winter 1922-23. Some of the measures comprised in (B) above are still in operation, e.g., pastsanctions of grants by the Unemployment Grants Committee and the Ministry ofTransport. The Export Credits Scheme continues, and schemes approved under theTrade Facilities Act are in progress. In June 1922. the Unemployment Grants Committee and the Ministry of Transportissued circular letters to Local Authorities inviting them to submit schemes for works of public utility, which. Avith assistance from State funds, might be undertaken for the relief of unemployment in their respective areas. Approved schemes areassisted by grants made on the same bases as heretofore. In the case of schemesassisted by the Unemployment Grants Committee, particulars of grants already sanctioned are set out below. In September .1922, the Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries issued circularletters to County Councils (except the London County Council) and DrainageAuthorities, inviting them to submit schemes of land drainage which, if approved,might be assisted on.fundamentally the same conditions as those aoplicable in the [10457] . B 3 '/ ':U.'.''-case of schemes assisted during the previous year. Ail applications were, to bereceived in the case of Drainage Authorities on or before December. .1, 1922,and in the case of County Councils (Agricultural Committees) on or before december 16, 1922. County Councils were also circulated, with regard to schemesfor ,the supply of water to farms, the conditions of assistance from the Ministry ofAgriculture and Fisheries remaining substantially the. same as the previous winter,with the exception that the Ministry, instead of advancing the whole cost ot any scheme and recovering a proportion from the owners concerned, will make grants to cover part only of the total cost of each scheme. Operations on these schemesceased after the 16th June, 1923. Particulars of grants sanctioned are shown below(see III, item 6). On the 30th November, 1922, the Minister of Labour, in the House of Commons,outlined the manner in which measures taken by the late Government would becontinued and extended. The additional sums promised in extension of existingfunds are set out below : Unemployment Grants Committee (for grants on the basis of 60 per cent, of Wages Bill) ... ... ... ... 600,000 Land Drainage ... ... ... ....... 170,000 Afforestation ... ... ... . ... ... ... 100,000 Acceleration of Government contracts Office of Works ... ... ... 375,000 General Post Office ... ... 946,000 - 1,321,000 It was also then announced that guarantees under the Trade Facilities ActScheme would be made available up to 50,000,000 ( 25,000,000 extra); that theExport Credits Scheme would be extended if necessary; and that the LocalAuthorities concerned would be asked to co-operate in putting in hand the manchester-Liverpool " Road, which would involve an expenditure of about 3,000,000, half of it from the Road Fund. In December 1922, the Unemployment Grants Committee issued a furthercircular letter to Local Authorities inviting them to submit schemes... suitable forassistance on the basis of 60 per cent, of the Wages Bill, i.e., works the cost of whichis normally defrayed out of revenue and not by loan. The conditions under which grants may be sanctioned are substantially the same as those previously in force,except that in the case of Rural Districts the Committee have discretion to allow,where clearly necessary,, a modification of the conditions regarding the giving ofpreference to 75 per cent, ex-service men and the engagement of labour through theEmployment Exchanges. On the 12th December, 1922, the Minister of Labour, in the House of Commons,further, announced that, in addition to the acceleration of contracts by the PostOffice and Office of Works, previously described, the Admiralty would acceleratemiscellaneous works to a total of about 365,000; whilst the Home Office would putin hand certain accelerated building work, together with repairs to buildings,including Police Stations. On the 13th December, 1922, the Forestry Commission issued a press notice tothe effect that forestry grants; were available for the relief of unemployment onthe same general conditions as those applicable to grants made during the previouswinter. The sum of 100,000 referred to above is to be used partly for this purpose and partly for the purpose of relief schemes in Crown Forests and for additional work in the Commission^ Forests. ' Operations on these schemes ceased after the30th June, 1923.
